## 판결문 요약


416 Mich. 53 (1982)
330 N.W.2d 634
PEOPLE
v.
ADAMS
Docket No. 63780, (Calendar No. 1).
Supreme Court of Michigan.
Argued January 5, 1982.
Decided December 23, 1982.
Frank J. Kelley, Attorney General, Louis J. Caruso, Solicitor General, and Earl H. Morgan, Jr., Prosecuting Attorney, for the people.
Thomas & Rapp (by Robert W. Thomas) for the defendant.
LEVIN, J.
The defendant, John Edward Adams, was originally charged with armed robbery. He was convicted by a jury of three unarmed robberies and one larceny from the person following a holdup at a cocktail lounge.[1] The Court of Appeals *56 reversed because the trial judge refused to give defendant's requested instructions on attempted armed robbery and attempted unarmed robbery.[2] We reverse and reinstate the convictions.
In People v Lovett, 396 Mich. 101; 238 NW2d 44 (1976), the defendant was charged with armed robbery. This Court reversed the defendant's conviction of larceny from the person because the judge had refused to instruct, as requested by the defendant's lawyer, on the lesser included offense of attempted armed robbery. We said that attempted armed robbery is "necessarily included".
